snippet: As some survivors come back to the world of the living, they feel a chill of wariness, or worse, from neighbors.
abstract: Daru Journal; many survivors of Ebola epidemic in West Africa return home from treatment centers to face neighbors who are distant and cold, afraid of contracting the disease; circumstance is illustrated by experience of Jattu Lahai, who was greeted warily by neighbors in Daru, Sierra Leone, after her successful treatment; in some places, any association with one of the affected countries, however remote, is enough to set off suspicion and ostracism.

byline.contributor: Yiting Sun contributed reporting from Accra, Ghana.

lead_paragraph: As some survivors come back to the world of the living, they feel a chill of wariness, or worse, from neighbors.

headline.main: Surviving Ebola, but Untouchable Back Home
headline.print_headline: Surviving Ebola, but Untouchable Back Home
